Adonai.note: Hebrew title meaning 'Lord,' used reverently to address God.

Advocate.note: Intercessor who pleads our cause before the Father (1 John 2:1).

Almighty.note: Attribute emphasizing God's unlimited power and authority.

Alpha and Omega.note: The One who is first and last, beginning and end (Revelation 22:13).

Beloved Son.note: Title referring to Jesus, emphasizing His special relationship with God the Father.

Bread of Life.note: Sustainer who feeds the soul unto eternal life (John 6:35).

Bridegroom.note: Loving Lord who comes for His bride with joy (Matthew 9:15).

Christ.note: Greek translation of 'Messiah,' meaning 'Anointed One,' referring to Jesus.

Cornerstone.note: Foundation upon which God’s household is built (Ephesians 2:20).

Creator.note: Title emphasizing God as the origin and maker of all creation.

Door.note: Only entry into salvation and safety for the flock (John 10:9).

El Elyon.note: Hebrew title meaning 'God Most High,' emphasizing God's sovereignty.

El Olam.note: Hebrew title meaning 'Everlasting God,' emphasizing God's eternal nature.

El Shaddai.note: Hebrew title meaning 'God Almighty,' indicating God's power and sufficiency.

Elohim.note: Hebrew term for God, used to denote His supreme power and authority.

Everlasting Father.note: Fatherly care that spans ages without end (Isaiah 9:6).

Faithful and True.note: Rider who judges in righteousness, steadfast in all His words (Revelation 19:11).

Father.note: Reference to God's paternal relationship with His creation and believers.

First and the Last.note: Title indicating God's eternal nature, encompassing all of time and existence.

God.note: Supreme being and creator of the universe, central figure of worship in biblical religion.

Good Shepherd.note: Guardian who knows His sheep and lays down His life for them (John 10:11).

Great High Priest.note: Mediator who sympathizes with our weakness and opens the way (Hebrews 4:14–16).

He.note: Pronoun referring to God, indicating His divine nature and authority.

His.note: Pronoun referring to God, indicating possession or relationship.

Holy One.note: Title highlighting God's absolute purity and holiness.

Holy Spirit.note: Third person of the Trinity, representing God's active presence and power.

I AM.note: Divine self-identification given to Moses, expressing God's eternal existence.

I AM THAT I AM.note: Self-existent One who simply is, from everlasting to everlasting (Exodus 3:14).

Immanuel.note: Alternate spelling of Emmanuel: God with us (Matthew 1:23).

Jehovah.note: Traditional transliteration of YHWH, the personal and covenantal name of God in Hebrew.

Jesus.note: Central figure of Christianity, believed to be the incarnate Son of God, Savior of humanity.

Jesus Christ.note: Combination of 'Jesus' (Savior) and 'Christ' (Anointed One), emphasizing His divine mission.

King of Kings.note: Supreme sovereign over all rulers and realms (Revelation 19:16).

Kyrios.note: Greek title meaning 'Lord,' used frequently in the New Testament referring to Jesus and God.

Lamb of God.note: Pure sacrifice who takes away the sin of the world (John 1:29).

Light of the World.note: Radiance that dispels darkness and guides the way (John 8:12).

Lion of Judah.note: Royal strength and rightful heir who prevails (Revelation 5:5).

Lord.note: Title denoting authority and divinity, commonly applied to God and Jesus.

Lord of Lords.note: Highest Master before whom every knee will bow (1 Timothy 6:15).

Morning Star.note: Harbinger of dawn and hope unfailing (Revelation 22:16).

O Lord.note: Expression of reverence and supplication directed toward God.

only Begotten Son.note: Phrase emphasizing the unique divine Sonship of Jesus.

Prince of Peace.note: Ruler whose reign brings wholeness and rest (Isaiah 9:6).

Redeemer.note: Title emphasizing God’s role in liberating humanity from sin and spiritual bondage.

Resurrection and the Life.note: Victor over death who grants life everlasting (John 11:25).

Righteous Judge.note: Upright arbiter who rewards the faithful (2 Timothy 4:8).

Savior.note: Refers to Jesus Christ as the one who delivers humanity from sin and eternal death.

Son.note: Refers specifically to Jesus Christ, highlighting His relationship as the Son of God.

Son of the Living God.note: Title affirming Jesus’ divine nature and unique relationship to God the Father.

Spirit of God.note: Refers to the Holy Spirit, indicating God’s active presence and influence.

Spirit of Truth.note: Guide into all truth who glorifies the Son (John 16:13–14).

the Word.note: Refers to Jesus Christ as God’s communication and revelation to humanity.

Trinity.note: Christian doctrine expressing God as three distinct persons in one divine essence.

True Vine.note: Source of fruitfulness—apart from Him we can do nothing (John 15:1,5).

Us.note: Pronoun indicating the plurality of God, often used in reference to the Trinity.

Way, Truth, and Life.note: Only path to the Father and fullness of life (John 14:6).

Wonderful Counselor.note: Wisdom from heaven that guides with comfort and might (Isaiah 9:6).

Word of Life.note: Eternal message made flesh and declared to us (1 John 1:1).

Yahweh.note: The personal and sacred Hebrew name for God, expressing His eternal existence.

angel.note: Heavenly messenger who carries out God’s word (Hebrews 1:14).

angels.note: Hosts that minister, protect, and worship before God (Psalm 103:20).

archangel.note: High-ranking messenger heard at the Lord’s return (1 Thessalonians 4:16).

archangels.note: Chief messengers serving God’s purposes in battle and proclamation (Jude 9).

cast out devils.note: KJV phrasing for expelling unclean spirits by authority (Mark 16:17).

casting out devils.note: Work of the Kingdom as unclean spirits are expelled (Matthew 12:28).

cherub.note: Throne guardian depicted with wings and awe (Genesis 3:24).

cherubim.note: Heavenly guardians attending God’s presence and holiness (Exodus 25:18–20).

demon.note: Unclean spirit opposing God’s work, subject to Christ’s authority (Mark 1:34).

demons.note: Unclean spirits cast out by Jesus and His followers (Luke 10:17).

devil.note: Accuser and adversary; defeated by the Lamb (Revelation 12:10–11).

devils.note: KJV plural term for demonic spirits (Mark 16:17).

evil spirit.note: Malignant spirit troubling or deceiving people (Acts 19:15–16).

evil spirits.note: Malignant spirits subject to Christ’s name (Mark 1:27).

exorcism.note: Deliverance ministry performed in Jesus’ name (Mark 16:17).

fallen angel.note: Rebellious being who left proper place and faces judgment (Jude 6).

fallen angels.note: Rebellious beings reserved for judgment (2 Peter 2:4).

familiar spirit.note: Spirit consulted in occult practice—strictly forbidden (Leviticus 19:31).

familiar spirits.note: Forbidden spirits sought by mediums (1 Samuel 28:7).

Gabriel.note: Messenger who announces God’s saving plans (Luke 1:19,26).

legion.note: Name given by many spirits possessing a man—driven out by Christ (Mark 5:9).

living creature.note: One of the visionary beings around God’s throne (Ezekiel 1:5).

living creatures.note: Visionary beings full of eyes who worship without rest (Revelation 4:6–8).

messenger of satan.note: Harasser allowed to buffet but not to triumph (2 Corinthians 12:7).

Michael.note: Archangel who contends for God’s people (Daniel 10:13; Revelation 12:7).

oppression.note: Heavy pressure of the enemy; the Anointed breaks yokes (Acts 10:38).

possessed with devils.note: KJV phrase for those under demonic control (Matthew 8:16).

possession.note: State of control by unclean spirits—overthrown by Christ (Mark 5:8).

powers.note: Authorities in the heavenly realm, disarmed by the cross (Colossians 2:15).

principalities.note: Ruling powers in the unseen realm, subject to Christ (Colossians 2:15).

principality.note: Ruling spiritual power opposed to God’s people (Ephesians 6:12).

satyr.note: Creature named in desolation oracles; haunt of ruins (Isaiah 13:21, KJV).

satyrs.note: Plurals in prophetic desolation scenes (Isaiah 34:14, KJV).

seraph.note: Fiery attendant who cries holy and purifies lips (Isaiah 6:6–7).

seraphim.note: Burning ones who proclaim God’s holiness without ceasing (Isaiah 6:2–3).

spirit forces.note: Catch‑all for unseen hosts—either holy or hostile—at work (2 Kings 6:16–17).

divination.note: Deceptive power that mimics revelation; silenced by the apostle (Acts 16:16–18).

wickedness.note: Evil in high places opposed by prayer and armor of God (Ephesians 6:12).

unclean spirit.note: Impure spirit that Jesus rebukes and expels (Mark 1:23–26).

unclean spirits.note: Many impure spirits driven out by His authority (Matthew 8:16).

watcher.note: Heavenly observer in Daniel’s visions, sign of divine oversight (Daniel 4:13).

watchers.note: Heavenly observers decreeing and reporting by God’s authority (Daniel 4:17).

Artemis.note: Greek goddess of Ephesus whose cult opposed the gospel (Acts 19:27–28).

Asherah.note: Canaanite goddess associated with groves and forbidden worship (2 Kings 23:7).

Ashtaroth.note: Plural/variant linked to fertility cults (1 Samuel 7:4).

Ashteroth.note: Variant rendering of Ashtoreth in some texts (Judges 2:13).

Ashtoreth.note: Phoenician goddess of fertility; Israel rebuked for serving her (1 Kings 11:5).

Baal.note: Canaanite storm god confronted by the Lord’s prophets (1 Kings 18:21).

Baal Zebub.note: Philistine god of Ekron consulted by a king—condemned (2 Kings 1:2).

Baalim.note: Plural reference to Baal idols across the land (Judges 2:11).

Bel.note: Babylonian deity brought low by the living God (Isaiah 46:1).

Chemosh.note: Moabite god whose worship ensnared Israel (1 Kings 11:7).

Dagon.note: Philistine god humbled before the Ark of God (1 Samuel 5:3–4).

Diana.note: Roman name used in Acts for Artemis of the Ephesians (Acts 19:27–28).

Golden Calf.note: Idol fashioned in impatience; a stark warning against apostasy (Exodus 32:4).

Hermes.note: Greek messenger god mistaken for Paul at Lystra (Acts 14:12).

Jupiter.note: Roman sky god (Zeus) whose temple stood in Lystra (Acts 14:13).

Mercurius.note: KJV form of Hermes, honored by the crowd (Acts 14:12).

Mercury.note: Latin form of Hermes; crowd confusion rebuked by the apostles (Acts 14:12–15).

Merodach.note: Babylonian god (Marduk) judged powerless before the Lord (Jeremiah 50:2).

Milcom.note: Ammonite deity leading to detestable practices (1 Kings 11:5).

Molech.note: Ammonite idol associated with child sacrifice—abomination (Leviticus 18:21).

Nebo.note: Babylonian deity carried into captivity, shown worthless (Isaiah 46:1–2).

Queen of heaven.note: Title invoked in idolatrous worship condemned by Jeremiah (Jeremiah 7:18).

Rimmon.note: Syrian deity whose house Naaman sought pardon to enter (2 Kings 5:18).

Tammuz.note: Deity mourned in visions—a grief God rejects (Ezekiel 8:14).

Zeus.note: Greek sky god whose honor the apostles refused (Acts 14:12–15).
